addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

1
o
Junij
1592.
M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
Received not before
e 27 of June.

page.lettertext:
fol.2r
May it please yo
r
good L. The 24 day of
May, w
t
in a daies jorney of
steenwicke,
I re-
ceaved her
Ma
ties
l
re
s to
e
General states
,
and to my self, w
t
one from yo
r
L. w
ch
were
dated
e 8 and
e 9 of
e same. Advertised
thereby of
e pleasure of her Hig
nes
, that I should
deale w
t
e
Councel,
and
Count Maurice
, aswell
as w
t
e states, for sending further succo
rs
to the
service of
e
King,
I parted presently upon it,
and came
e same day, where
e Count was en-
camped. Having signified there unto him
her Ma
ties
desire, and used requisit persuasion,
to move him to advance it, he made me this
answear,
at he was very well assured of the
states resolution, not to send for this present any
more into
France:
for that
e contrey had as-
sented to a large contribution, for
e atchieving
heere of those attemptes, w
ch
are determined this
sommer: w
ch
also tend to
e assuring of the
Province of Frise, and
at their honor was enga-
ged in
e enterprise of steenwicke. Wherupon
for himself, as it was not a mater,
at belon
ged unto him, but to
e states of
e contrey, so
he thought it very hard, to be pressed therunto,
not willing to intermeddle ether one way or
other. And astouching
e troupes, w
ch
her Ma
tie
required of her owne intertenment, he was fully
persuaded,
at assoone as they were gone,
e states
would revoke their forces out of France: and
at
besides it would occasion a great discontentm
t
among
e people of these Provinces, and cause
at
nothing will be done ether heere or in France:
w
ch
would prejudice exceedingly both her Ma
tie
and
them. This was
e substance of his answear unto me:
fol.2v
wherunto I replied,
at howsoever
e states had
already resolved, to imploie their forces heere
at home, both her Ma
tie
and they had but onely
one designe, w
ch
was to ruine
e Enemie, by
all
e meanes they could devise. And seing in
all apparance, he was already reduced to suche
termes of extremitie, as an opportunitie nowe
served, to precipitat all his power, and that
very shortly, by assisting
e king w
t
suche str
e
gth
as they were able, they could not answear
in reason to their frindes and allies, for their
wilfull neglect of a notable advantage. And
to that w
ch
he objected,
at they had levied a sub-
sidie, in regard of their owne estate, and were
nowe in suche an action, as they could not well
give over, w
t
e credit of
e contrey, or the peo-
ples satisfaction, it importing
e deliverance
of a principal Province, from subjection of
e
Enemie, her Ma
tie
in her letter had made
sufficient answear, That if
e Enemie in
France prevaile of his designe, his losses heere
at home of a fewe litle townes will soone be
recovered. And for contenting of
e people,
w
ch
can not happely conceave, howe
e expending
of their mony, to support a forraine Prince, can
redounde unto
e contrey muche more benefici-
all, then it may doe heere among themselves, in
these intended exploites, w
ch
are done before
their eies, are understoode of them all, and
carie a kinde of certaintie of that successe that
they desire, That I signified was a point, in w
ch
his owne good endevor, w
t
e rest of
e Gover-
nors, and those
at have
e maneging of
e af-
faires of their state, was specially required.
fol.3r
For if they would resolve, to concurre in some
good forme of a publicke Remonstrance, and
travel in suche sort, as they were able with
e
people, it would undoubtedly prove easie, to
compasse their good liking. But howsoever
they were inclined, for w
t
holding of their owne
forces, her Ma
tie
did expect,
at they would not
refuse her, for
e enseignes demaunded of the
Englishe assistance. For they might drawe out
of
Holland,
for a present supplie, as good as 15
companies of their owne pay, w
ch
were reser-
ved heare behinde, for defense against
e Enemie,
while
e armie is at steenwicke. They
have also lately intertened, as I writte unto
yo
r
L.
e 17 of
e last, 2000 men of
Juliers,
to be imploied in their service, upon certaine
weekes warning: so as nothing can impeache,
but
at
e intention of her Ma
tie
for
e use of those
at she requireth, should be willingly accorded.
There was nothing said to this,
at was greatly
material, nor to divers other pointes, that I
proposed to like effect. But he concluded all
his answear,
at for his owne particular, he would
nether make nor marre
e mater, but leave it
to
e states. To
e self same
purpose, as I had dealed w
t
e Count, I dealt
e
next day after w
t
e Councel of Estate: who
thought
e motion out of season, their Campe
being setled in
e siege of steenwicke:
e taking
wherof would free
e land of
Frise
of a great
contribution, amounting yerely at
e lest to
24000
li
sterling, w
ch
is paied to
e Enemie by
e frontier inhabitants: for w
ch
they thought it im-
possible, to gette
e states to yelde unto it.
They
also
urged therew
t
all,
at
e affaires of
e
fol.3v
that
e affaires of
e
King did alter very muche,
and were nowe in an other state, then at the
time of
e date of her Ma
ties
letter. For they had
letters from sundrie places,
at
Parma
was retur-
ned, and in all probablitie, would give some on-
sette at his comming. And where her Hig
nes
did
require 2000 of her owne subjectes, to be shipped
out of hand they stoode upon
e Contract, that
they could
not
in equitie be otherwise disposed, then
e Contrey shall appoint: for
at her Ma
tie
hath cau-
tions, for
e answearing of her charges. In con-
clusion they tooke it, for a mater appertening to
e states of
e contrey, and so remitted me to them.
As I had formerly replied to
e
Countes allegations, I delivered
e same to
e Coun-
cel againe, to witte in suche pointes, as their spee-
ches agreed; and declared besides to their further
objections, that they knewe well enough, they
were able for a time, to spare a good power to
e
assisting of
e King, and yet retaine sufficient
strength, for defense of all their places. And
as for
at, w
ch
they had pleaded, upon
e mater of
remboursement, it was not greatly pertinent.
For in a manifest case, of suche advantage to
e
cause, they should deale very strictly w
t
her
Ma
tie
if having suffered those of Holland, to send
certaine Regiments into France, w
t
out asking
e
advise of
e rest of
e Provinces, they would sticke
at her demaunde, w
ch
is so orderly imparted,
and desired at their handes. Againe, al-
beit they were unwilling, to take any order in this
mater, but put me over to
e states, they were
not ignorant notw
t
standing,
at
e states inter-
medling in a cause of this q
a
litie, was a flatte
usurpation, and
at
all
e actions of these warres, by
fol.4r
graunt of
e Contract, were belonging onely to
her Ma
tie
and to
e college of
e Councel, whereby
her Hig
nes
had autoritie, as muche as all
e Councel,
to appoint
e imploiment of their forces, for
e
service of
e contrey. I wished them at last,
that although they would not send any more of their
owne, they should not stand w
t
her Ma
tie
for the 14
Englishe bandes, w
ch
if they would not permitte to
be presently sent, being most of them there, and en-
gaged in
e siege, yet because it was hoped, that
in 10 daies after,
e service would be ended, and
because they had besides them, sufficient forces of
e
contrey, to perfourme
e rest
at they intended, for
e
attemptes of this sommer, they should not make
any further question, when steenwicke was re-
duced. To w
ch
effect I did desire,
at they
would falle in consultation and give
e states
their best advise. But to that they would
not answear. I had this conference w
t
the
Councel
e 25 of May, in
e campe before steen-
wicke. But because they left me to
e states,
to whome her Ma
ties
letter was addressed expres-
sely, and were residing at
e hage, I came hi-
ther therupon w
t
all possible speede: where I
founde their assemblie dissolved for a time, and
divers of
e Deputies departed home into their
Provinces, so as those
at were remaining, made
some doubt of breaking open her Ma
ties
letter, for
want of their being in competent number. But
when I had declared to some in particular, that
this Recesse of
e states, at suche a time as the
contrey had greatest neede of their service, would
seeme a practise for
e nones, to defeate her Hig
nes
of
her purpose, and
at I thought she would goe for-
ward, w
t
out attending their meeting, they assem-
bled then as many, as were abiding heere in place,
fol.4r
and used divers communications and com-
ings too and fro, to debate
e mater with
me: w
ch
was all to one effect, w
t
e speeches of
e Count, and Councel of estate. But this they
added more,
at for their levies in Juliers, they
were for
at provision, w
ch
they made for
Bri-
taine
, and not to be imploied in any other
part: for w
ch
also their shippes, w
ch
they pro-
mised for their portion, are all in a readines:
so as nowe they doe attend, w
at
her Hig
nes
will
resolve. Moreover for
e companies
in Holland, w
ch
I alleaged they might use in
lieu of
e Englishe; they had freshe intelligence
out of
Brabant,
at
Mondragon
was in feeld
w
t
1500 footemen, and towardes 400 horse:
and had taken
Sgravenwesel,
w
ch
was a place
of good strength appertening to these contreis.
From thens, as it seemeth, he marcheth towardes
Tournhout
and
Westelo,
w
ch
are also castels in
o
r
possession: and as his forces shall augment, as
by report they doe daily, they feare some greater
mater. For prevention wherof they might not
suffer those troupes to be sent out of Holland.
Lastly they told me,
at they had newly given
leave to their Coronels in France, who they
thought at this present, had scarce in all a 1000
men, to raise their numbers to two thousand
four hundred, w
ch
they were in hope would
satisfie
e King, considering their estate: as
they doubted not also, but her Ma
tie
but her
Ma
t
would be moved not to presse them any
more, upon notice of as muche, as they had de-
clared, w
ch
they praied me to certifie. For
as yet they were uncertaine, whether in a
fol.5r
mater of that consequence, being fewer then
they should be, and therfore not autorised to as-
semble as a college, they might answear her Ma
tie
by way of a letter: w
ch
yet they meant to putte
againe in further deliberation. I am
borne in hand by
M
r
Buzenval
,
at he hath
dealt very earnestly, to helpe this mater forward,
being so commaunded by
e King: but hath
had no other answear, then
at w
ch
I have signi-
fied. To give yo
r
L. some notice
of my privat persuasion, If her Ma
tie
at first,
as she requested them to yelde some greater aide
unto
e King, had required therew
t
all in absolut
maner,
at
e 14 Englishe bandes should be pre-
sently embarked, I thinke they had not made
any great opposition, and I am sure it had im-
peached
e composing of their campe, whereby there
had bin hope,
at in
e end they would have spa-
red some enseignes of their owne. More
over I hold it my duty to certifie yo
r
L. that
where her Ma
tie
doth account, that
e 14 footec
o
-
panies should make 2000 men, they will not
reache to
at number, in common conjecture, by
seven or eight hundred at
e lest. For there
are almost 300 comprehended in
e allowance
of
e dead paies and of suche persons in every
company, as never come to service. It is also
supposed that their other defectes, for want of ren-
forcement out of
England,
and by reason of
other accidents, and their losses in this siege, toge-
ther w
t
e number that will runne from their
captaines, before they come to be embarked will
stretche in all likelihood, to twice as many more.
For there were slaine and hurt, before I parted
from
e campe, not so fewe as a 100 Englishe: of
fol.5v
w
ch
there were 60 in one day sent to
Campen,
Horne,
Enchusen,
and
Amsterdam.
And no doubt
they have decreased continually sins, and will
doe more and more, as they come to harder service
in assaulting or otherwise. Upon this weak-
nesse of
e companies both
e states and
e Coun-
cel did earnestly insist,
at being drawen away
from hens, they should be forced out of hand to dis-
solve their armie,
e King should receave but a
small relief of men, and at last by
at meanes no-
thing would be done of
e one side or
e other.
Because I doe presume,
at
S
r
Francis
Vere
, and
S
r
Robert Sidney
will advertise yo
r
L.
of all that hath passed, sins their first sitting downe,
I should but overtrouble yow w
t
my particular
relation. There is very good hope,
at we shall
carie away
e place: and we looke to under-
stand it w
t
in foure or five daies. At my be-
ing there,
e towne was blocked on every side,
approches made into
e counterscarffe, and
e most
of their gabbions placed already. And by this time
I suppose, they have planted their artillerie: of
w
ch
there were 47 great peeces, and a 11 for
e
feelde: wherew
t
they purpose to batter in foure se-
veral places, for
e making of two breaches. They
have also made a cavallier, upon w
ch
they appoint
to place some peeces of ordinance, for skouring
e
rampartes, at
e time of
e batterie. Besides
ei
have sette certaine pioners a worke to sappe the
walles, and divers ingeno
rs
to devise artificial
fires, and are determined to putte all in executi
o
in one day, for
e more astonnishement of
e Enemie.
The towne is very litle, and w
at
garrison is in it,
we can not conjecture. For
ei have caried
fol.6r
themselves very souldierlike, and having made
many salies, never left us a prisoner, by whome
we might learne
e state of
e towne. S
r
Francis Vere hath bin shotte w
t
a harquebuze in
e
smalle of his left legge, and his brother
Horace Vere
in one of his armes: but I hope they will bothe re-
cover it quickly. The hindrance
of
at w
ch
was intended at Enchusen, proceeded
of
e Enemie, who not fully contented w
t
the
person alone of
e principal partie, that was con-
triver of
e practise, required him to bring
some other pledges besides, and more then could be
well perfourmed, but w
t
losse of longer time,
then could conveniently be spared, before
e siege
of steenwicke. But
e partie doth yet conti-
nue in
e handes of
e Enemie, and his pollicie
undiscovered. In
e Marchants
buisnes, w
ch
her Ma
tie
recommendeth, I have tra-
velled as muche as is possible for me, and I
doe
thinke they doe rest indifferently well pleased.
The decision of certaine pointes, was differred by
the states, w
t
e companies good liking, to
e end
of certaine monethes, w
ch
when they be resumed, I
will helpe to end to their content.
And so be-
seeching yo
r
L. to acquaint her Ma
tie
w
t
my dea-
linges, I take my humble leave.
At
e Hage. June 1 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
